unless otherwise noted, all figures in this emodule are from gray’s anatomy for students, 3e, by drake , vogl, & mitchell, © 2015 by elsevier. this is a recommended resource click to continue click to continue click to continue emodule tutorial emodule tutorial emodule tutorial

unit 5 overview previous next the skeleton is quite sensibly divided into an axial division and an appendicular division. the axial division consists of the skull, vertebral column and bony thorax. in unit 1, you were introduced to the vertebral column and bony thorax. in unit 2, you learned the anatomy of the skull. in unit 3, you studied the appendicular division of the skeleton, including the pectoral girdle and upper limb, and the pelvic girdle and lower limb. in addition, you learned the fascial compartments of the limbs and the peripheral vascular system. now, in cpc-3, unit 5, you will learn the anatomy of the musculoskeletal system, including the articulations , movements, major muscles and nerves of the limbs.

prior to lab 16, complete exercise 16a, a short self-learning module that describes the organization of the distal limbs. the lab will begin with an ap-based quiz on these slms. lab 16 consists of two stations, set up in duplicate in each lab. at station 16.1 you will learn about the muscles and nerves of the forearm. at station 16.2 you will learn about the muscles and nerves of the leg and foot. prior to the lab, you must review the content of exercises 16.1 - 16.4 so that your time in lab is used efficiently. the materials for station 16.1 are set out in duplicate on the left side of the room for groups 1 and 2 to start with. the materials for station 16.2 are set out in duplicate on the right side of the room for groups 3 and 4 to start with. after two hours, you will switch and complete the other exercise. do not ask your colleagues to switch early. they are entitled to learn, using the materials provided to them, for the full two hours, without pressure to hurry. if you finish the first exercise before 2 hours is up, go on a field trip to grant’s museum of anatomy or go take a break so that you come back refreshed and ready to learn some more. lab 16 instructions previous take me to exercise selection

using the emodule use this emodule before labs to prepare for them, during labs to guide your studies, and after labs as a review tool. to navigate the module, use the next button at the bottom of the pages, swipe next or press the right arrow key to move forward one page at a time. use the menu, available by clicking “menu” at the top, to navigate to specific slides. use search to quickly find instances of relevant terms. use the previous button at the bottom of the pages, swipe previous or press the left arrow key to move back one page at a time. lab 16 exercise 16a prelab slm 16.1 forearm 16.2 the leg … previous next

previous got it, let’s move on conventions used in the emodule with age, wear and tear, info information that has implications for health and disease is introduced on a blue bar and continued below the bar: and how the superior and inferior articular facets of adjacent vertebrae articulate with one another. note how they fit together, tas k tasks, introduced on a pink bar and continued below the bar in bold, are actions that you should take to help you understand the content: an intervertebral disc can herniate, such that the nucleus pulposus…. the film button appears on the bottom bar of slides where a video accompanies tasks or explanations. the photo button appears at the bottom of slides where a photo accompanies tasks. some words are followed by an icon ; click the icon to jump to related slides. click the icon to jump back. some words are followed by an icon ; click the icon to see a definition. words / phrases in purple denote concepts with which you should become familiar. the slide talk icon appears on the top bar of slides containing a recording of me explaining concepts

lab 16 exercise selection select an exercise to begin: lab 16 stations 16.1 the forearm 16.1 the forearm 16.1 the forearm 16.2 the leg, ankle and foot 16.2 the leg, ankle and foot 16.2 the leg, ankle and foot if you finish early… 16.3 field trip 16.3 field trip 16.3 field trip review lab 16 quizlandia 16 quizlandia 16 quizlandia 16 pre-lab slm 16a slm organization of the distal limbs 16a slm organization of the distal limbs 16a slm organization of the distal limbs previous

16a organization of the distal limbs back to station selection next when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to describe the general structure of the forearm. part 1: the forearm

16a compartments of the forearm like the arm, the muscles of the forearm are organized into an anterior (flexor-pronator) compartment and a posterior (extensor-supinator) compartment. muscles in each compartment share common actions and innervations. the deep fascia of the forearm, the antebrachial fascia, surrounds the muscles, deep to the skin and superficial fascia. the anterior and posterior compartments are separated by: a lateral intermuscular septum that extends between the antebrachial fascia and the radius the radius the antebrachial interosseous membrane that joins the radius and ulna, and the ulna 2 previous next muscles of the forearm act at the wrist to cause flexion / extension and abduction / adduction. other muscles of the forearm send their tendons into the hand to cause flexion / extension of the digits. these are the extrinsic muscles of the hand . intrinsic muscles of the hand are generally responsible for abduction / adduction of the digits. they include the thenar muscles which act on the thumb and form the thenar eminence at the base of the thumb.

16a nomenclature is your friend! 3 previous next while the names of the muscles of the forearm and hand are daunting at first glance, pretty quickly, you will learn that the names are very descriptive and informative. for instance: muscles that act on the wrist have the word carpi in their names. that’s helpful info! muscles that act on the fingers have the word digitorum in their names. ditto! muscles that act on the thumb have the word pollicis in their names. ditto! muscles that are flexors have the word flexor in their names. you get the idea! muscles that are extensors have the word extensor in their names. muscles that are abductors have the word abductor in their names. muscles that are adductors have the word adductor in their names. muscles on the lateral (radial) aspect of the forearm have radialis in their names. muscles on the medial (ulnar) aspect of the forearm have ulnaris in their names. sometimes, two muscles might have the same attachments or the same action at the same joint. they are differentiated using descriptors, for instance: if one is longer than the other, it has longus in its name and the other has brevis in its name. if one is superficial to the other, it has superficialis in its name and the other has profundus in its name. the moral of this story is to use the names of the muscles to your advantage in learning their actions, locations, and, in some cases, their relative positions.

16a transitional zones 4 previous next transitional zones connect regions of the upper limb. you learned, in lab 15, about the axilla. lab 16 picks up where lab 15 left off, with a description of the cubital fossa, through which structures pass between the arm and forearm. the cubital fossa is the triangular region anterior to the elbow. later in the lab will come a description of the carpal tunnel, through which structures pass between the forearm and hand.

16a the anterior compartment of the forearm 5 previous next the two muscles that pronate the forearm are also in this compartment. both have the word pronator in their names. because these are the primary actions of the muscles of the anterior compartment of the forearm, it is described, functionally, as the “flexor-pronator compartment”. all muscles in this compartment are innervated by the median nerve, with one-and-a-half exceptions. the exceptions are innervated by the ulnar nerve. the muscles are organized into three layers. the superficial layer consists of four muscles (red). one is a pronator of the forearm, and the other three muscles flex the wrist joint. the middle layer consists of one muscle (green) that flexes the mcp and pip joints of the four fingers. the deep layer consists of two muscles (blue). one is the only muscle that flexes the dip joints of the four fingers. the other is the only muscle that flexes the interphalangeal joint of the thumb. notice: the deeper the muscle, the more distal its insertion, and therefore, the more distal its action. tendons arising from the muscles of the anterior compartment of the forearm cross the anterior aspect of the wrist and digits; they therefore act to flex the wrist, mcp, pip and dip joints . many of these muscles have the word flexor in their names.

16a the posterior compartment of the forearm 6 previous next the second muscle that supinates the forearm, in addition to the biceps brachii, is also in this compartment. it is called the supinator . because these are the primary actions of the muscles of the posterior compartment of the forearm, it is described, functionally, as the “extensor-supinator compartment”. all muscles in this compartment are innervated by the radial nerve . the muscles are organized into two layers. the superficial layer consists of six muscles (red). one acts act the elbow. the others extend the wrist and fingers. tendons arising from the muscles of the posterior compartment of the forearm cross the posterior aspect of the wrist and digits, and therefore act to extend the wrist, mcp, pip and dip joints. many of these muscles have the word extensor in their names. there are four muscles in the deep layer, two of which are seen at the level of this cross section. three muscles of this layer act on the thumb, and the fourth acts on the index finger.

16a there is no abductor / adductor compartment 7 previous next muscles of the anterior compartment of the forearm flex the wrist. muscles of the posterior compartment of the forearm extend the wrist. what muscles abduct and adduct the wrist? abduct your wrist. where must the tendons be positioned to cause this action? think, then click: adduct your wrist. where must the tendons be positioned to cause this action? think, then click: but, there are no medial and lateral compartments in the forearm! whattup?!? the answer lies in cooperation between muscles of the anterior and posterior compartments. muscles in both compartments, the tendons of which cross the medial aspect of the wrist, work synergistically to adduct the wrist. similarly, muscles in both compartments, the tendons of which cross the lateral aspect of the wrist, work synergistically to abduct the wrist. left hand

16a movement of the fingers 8 previous next in anatomical position: the palm of the hand faces forward and the dorsum of the hand faces backward; the thumb is on the lateral aspect of the hand and the little finger is on its medial aspect; the thumb and fingers are extended fully. abduction / adduction of the fingers occurs relative to the middle finger. the fingers stay in the plane of the hand. flexion curls fingers into the palm; decreasing the angle of the mcps, pips and dips. extension straightens the fingers, increasing the angle of these joints.

16a movement of the thumb 9 previous next in the fingers, abduction / adduction and flexion / extension occur at the mcps, pips and dip joints. similarly, in the thumb, these movements take place at the mcp and the ip joints. recall that the thumb is rotated 90° relative to the fingers. therefore, its movements occur in a plane rotated 90° relative to those of the fingers. thus, while abduction of the fingers occurs in the plane of the hand, abduction of the thumb takes it out of the plane of the hand. in anatomical position, the thumb is extended; it is in the plane of the hand, but pulled laterally away from the hand. flexion curls the thumb across the palm, rather than into the palm, as does flexion of the fingers opposition occurs at the carpometacarpal joint, primarily of the thumb. it cups the thumb into the palm of the hand, facilitating grip. the carpometacarpal joints of the fingers have a limited mobility.

previous next 16a organization of the distal limbs when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to describe the general structure of the leg and foot. part 2: the leg and foot

16a organization of the leg and zones of transition 11 previous next the leg extends from the knee joint to the talocrural joint . the deep fascia of the leg is the crural fascia. it is continuous with the periosteum of the tibia on the anteromedial aspect of the leg. it is continuous to the fascia lata, proximal to the knee. on your own leg. locate the popliteal fossa and tarsal tunnel tas k your own calf to confirm that the tibia is subcutaneous here. feel the length of the anteromedial aspect of tas k an anterior and a posterior intermuscular septum extend from the crural fascia to the fibula to define a lateral compartment of the leg. the tibia, fibula and crural interosseous membrane separate the anterior compartment and posterior compartments of the leg. the posterior compartment is further divided into a posterior superficial and a posterior deep compartment (not shown). major neurovascular structures pass between the thigh and the leg through the popliteal fossa, the diamond-shaped region posterior to the knee. structures pass between the leg and the foot through the tarsal tunnel, located posteroinferior to the medial malleolus.

16a tendon placement and muscle action 12 previous next talocrural joint, like the red arrow in the diagram. describe the action a muscle would have that pulled along this line. use the proper term. think about it and then click here, to check your answer: place your index finger vertically anterior to your tas k place your index finger vertically posterior to your talocrural joint, in line with your achilles tendon, like the green arrow in the diagram. describe the action a muscle would have that pulled along this line. use the proper term. think about it and then click here, to check your answer: repeat this exercise while placing your index finger vertically on the lateral and medial aspects of your foot. describe the action a muscle would have that pulled vertically along the lateral aspect of the foot (pink arrow)? think then click: the medial aspect of the foot (blue arrow)? think then click: if you think about this exercise when studying the muscles of the leg in the prosected specimen provided, their actions will be easy to intuit.

16a movement of the toes 13 previous next remove your shoes and socks, and follow along. tas k it will help if you think of your hands as feet; hold your hands palms down and the dorsum of the hand facing upward. your palms are analogous to the soles (inferior surface) of your feet and the dorsum of your hand is analogous to the dorsum (superior surface) of your feet. tendons that pull along the inferior surface of the toes (red arrow) cause them to curl under. keep in mind that the sole of the foot is analogous to the palm of the hand . what movement occurs at the mtp , pip and dip joints of the toes? think, then click: tendons that pull along the superior surface of the toes (green arrow) cause them to turn upwards. keep in mind that the dorsum of the foot is analogous to the dorsum of the hand. what movement occurs at the mcp, pip and dip joints of the toes? think, then click: the toes are capable of abduction and adduction at the mtp joints, just as the fingers are capable of abduction and adduction at the mcp joints. as in the hands, this movement pair is carried out by intrinsic muscles of the feet. you will not be taught about the abductors and adductors of the toes.

16a nomenclature is still your friend! 14 previous next while the names of the muscles of the leg and foot are daunting at first glance, pretty quickly, you will learn that the names are very descriptive and informative. for instance: muscles that act on the toes have the word digitorum in their names. ditto! muscles that act on the great toe have the word hallucis in their names. ditto! muscles that are flexors have the word flexor in their names. you get the idea! muscles that are extensors have the word extensor in their names. muscles on the medial (tibial) aspect of the leg have tibialis in their names. muscles on the lateral (fibular) aspect of the leg have fibularis in their names. sometimes, two muscles might have the same attachments or the same action at the same joint. they are differentiated using descriptors, for instance: if one is longer than the other, it has longus in its name and the other has brevis in its name. the moral of this story, once again, is to use the names of the muscles to your advantage in learning their actions, locations, and, in some cases, their relative positions.

16a borders of the popliteal fossa 15 previous next the popliteal fossa provides the major route by which structures pass between the thigh and the leg. it is a diamond-shaped regions posterior to the knee, analogous to the cubital fossa in the upper limb. immediately inferolateral and inferomedial to your popliteal fossa, palpate the two heads of the gastrocnemius muscles, which are known colloquially as the “calf muscles”. recall, from your study of the thigh, that the femoral artery and vein pass from the anterior compartment of the thigh, through the adductor hiatus, and into the popliteal fossa, where they are called the popliteal artery and vein. recall, further, that the tibial and common fibular divisions of the sciatic nerve pass from the posterior compartment of the thigh through the popliteal fossa to gain access to the leg. the popliteal fossa further contains lymphatic vessels and lymph nodes. feel the cord-like tendon of your biceps femoris superolateral to your knee. tas k similarly, feel the cord-like tendon of your semitendinosus superomedial to your knee. these muscles form the superolateral and superomedial borders of the popliteal fossa, respectively.

16a content of the popliteal fossa 16 previous next the neurovascular structures are packed in a large amount of adipose tissue and the popliteal fossa is enclosed superficially by the deep fascia of the leg, which is continuous superiorly with the fascia lata and inferiorly with the crural fascia. that is present in the popliteal fossa and because of the depth of the popliteal artery, a popliteal pulse can be difficult to palpate. because of the large amount of fat info the small saphenous vein and cutaneous nerves are located in the superficial fascia in the midline of the posterior leg. recall that the small saphenous vein is a continuation of the dorsal venous arch of the foot. at the popliteal fossa, the small saphenous vein pierces the deep fascia and unites with the popliteal vein.

16a the posterior compartment of the leg 17 previous next the posterior compartment of the leg is divided into the posterior superficial compartment and the posterior deep compartments. the posterior superficial compartment of the leg contains the “calf” muscles which insert via the calcaneal (achilles) tendon into the calcaneus. contraction of the calf muscles exerts a pull upward, posterior to the talocrural joint. what is therefore the action of the “calf muscles” ? think then click: the posterior deep compartment of the leg contains three muscles, the tendons of which pass behind the medial malleolus into the sole of the foot. one muscle pulls upward on the medial aspect of the foot. what is its action? think then click: the other muscles send their tendons across the inferior aspect of the toes. what is their action on the joints of the toes? think then click: all muscles in these compartments are innervated by the tibial nerve.

16a the lateral and anterior compartments of the leg 18 previous next the lateral compartment of the leg contains two muscles that arise from the fibula, and have fibularis in their names. one is longer than the other; what do you think the second words of their names are? i.e. their names are fibularis __________ and fibularis _________. think then click: their tendons pass posterior to the lateral malleolus, into the foot. both muscles pull upward on the lateral aspect of the foot. what is their action? think then click: the anterior compartment of the leg contains three muscles, the tendons of which pass anterior to the talocrural joint. what one action do they share? think, then click: . one muscle inserts into the medial aspect of the foot, pulling up on it. what is its action? think then click: . the other muscles send their tendons across the superior aspect of the toes. what is their action on the joints of the toes? think then click: recall that the common fibular nerve passes around the lateral aspect of the proximal leg. there it bifurcates into the superficial and deep fibular nerves. the superficial fibular nerve innervates the muscles of the lateral compartment of the leg, and the deep fibular nerve innervates the muscles of the anterior compartment of the leg.

16a quiz 19 previous you’ve reached the end of this exercise. do you want to take the end-of-exercise quiz now? let’s do it! i love anatomy! go to the quiz sorry….i’ll be back..(maybe) skip the quiz next
previous congratulations on finishing prelab slm 16a! back to exercise selection back to exercise selection back to exercise selection review 16a review 16a review 16a

16.1 the forearm back to station selection specimens an upper limb bone box an articulated bony upper limb an articulated bony hand 2 prosections of the wrist and hand 1 prosected full upper limb next

when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to identify and describe: the major muscles acting on the wrist and hand, and their actions the nerves of the forearm, including both their motor and sensory distributions 16.1 objectives 2 previous next

16.1 learning the forearm and hand 3 previous next in this exercise, you will learn the muscles and nerves of the forearm and hand and review its blood supply. you will start with the cubital fossa, the transitional zone between the arm and forearm. distal to the cubital fossa, you will use the fascial organization of the forearm to your advantage in your approach to learning this region. the forearm is divided into an anterior, “flexor-pronator” compartment and a posterior, “extensor-supinator” compartment. you’ll start learning the anatomy of the forearm with its anterior compartment.

16.1 the cubital fossa 4 previous next borders of the cubital fossa: its base is an imaginary line between the medial and lateral epicondyles, its lateral border is a muscle arising unwrap the prosected arm. identify the tas k superior to the lateral epicondyle, the brachioradialis, and its medial border is a muscle arising from the medial epicondyle, the pronator teres. identify, in the cubital fossa, from lateral to medial, the tendon of the biceps brachii, the brachial artery and the median nerve. other nerves have different relationships to the cubital fossa. lateral to the cubital fossa, identify the radial nerve between the brachialis and the brachioradialis. identify the ulnar nerve passing posterior to the medial epicondyle. superficial to the cubital fossa, and removed in the preparation of this specimen, is deep fascia, superficial fascia and skin. median cubital vein is located in the superficial fascia, a venous anastomosis between the cephalic and basilic veins. it is a common site for phlebotomy.

16.1 anterior compartment overview 5 previous next some general comments: the muscles of the anterior compartment are organized into three layers. the muscles of the first and second layer arise from the medial epicondyle of the humerus, the common flexor origin (cfo). the deeper the muscle, the more distal its action. all muscles in this compartment are innervated by the median nerve, with one-and-a-half exceptions. the exceptions are innervated by the ulnar nerve. the anterior compartment of the forearm can be referred to as the “flexor-pronator” compartment. muscles of this compartment pronate the forearm and flex the radiocarpal, metacarpophalangeal, and proximal and distal interphalangeal joints. the words “flexor” and “pronator” are common in the names of its muscles.

16.1 superficial layer 6 previous next identify the four superficial muscles that arise from the tas k medial epicondyle or common flexor origin, cfo. from lateral to medial, these are the pronator teres, the flexor carpi radialis, the palmaris longus and the flexor carpi ulnaris. between their names, the arrows on the diagram, and the direction of the muscles fibres in the prosection, you will find their actions to be obvious: the pronator teres is a pronator of the forearm (blue arrow). it pulls the midshaft of the radius medially, and thus turns the palm posteriorly. the flexor carpi radialis, palmaris longus and flexor carpi ulnaris are flexors of the wrist (green arrow). identify the tendons of the flexor carpi radialis, palmaris longus and flexor carpi ulnaris at the wrist. identify the insertion of the palmaris longus to the palmar aponeurosis, a thick condensation of deep fascia in the palm of the hand. the skin of the palm is bound tightly to the palmar aponeurosis, which is itself bound tightly to the flexor retinaculum. identify these tendons in your wrist and those of your colleagues. be aware that the palmaris longus is commonly absent either unilaterally or bilaterally. the muscles of the first layer include a pronator of the forearm and three flexors of the wrist.

16.1 middle layer 7 previous next identify the muscle bellies and tendons of the flexor digitorum superficialis. follow its tendons to the wrist where they pass deep to the flexor retinaculum, through the carpal tunnel, to the palm of the hand . gently probe between the tendons of the flexor carpi ulnars and palmaris longus. tas k each of the four tendons is distributed to a different finger. as illustrated, each tendon splits to insert onto both sides of the second phalange . flexor digitorum superficialis flexes the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints.

16.1 deep layer 8 previous next gently move the tendons of the flexor digitorum superficialis laterally to see tas k flexor digitorum superficialis medially to see the flexor pollicis longus muscle. as its name describes, it flexes the interphalangeal joint of the thumb. follow the tendons of flexor digitorum profundus and flexor pollicis longus through the carpal tunnel. deep to both, too deep to see in this prosection, is the pronator quadratus. as the red arrow indicates, it pulls horizontally across the distal radius and ulna to assist in pronation of the forearm. gently move the tendons of tas k another muscle deep to it, the flexor digitorum profundus. it, like the flexor digitorum superficialis, includes four tendons, one to each of the fingers. as illustrated, the tendons of flexor digitorum profundus pass between the split tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis to insert onto the distal phalanges . this is the only muscle that crosses and therefore flexes the dip joints.

16.1 the carpal tunnel 9 previous next extrinsic muscles of the hand are fleshy in the forearm and become tendinous as they approach the wrist. the tendons of these muscles are bound down at the wrist by the flexor and extensor retinacula. the long flexor tendons of the anterior compartment of the forearm cross the anterior aspect of the wrist via the carpal tunnel. the carpal tunnel is bounded on three sides by the carpal bones, and on its anterior aspect by the flexor retinaculum. along with the long flexor tendons, the median nerve passes through the carpal tunnel to gain access to the palm of the hand.

16.1 innervation by the median nerve 10 previous next trace the median nerve distally until it disappears behind the pronator teres. the median nerve runs in the plane between the middle and deep layers. as it travels distally, it sends muscular branches to all muscles of the anterior compartment of the forearm, with one-and-a-half exceptions . at the cubital fossa, identify the median nerve. tas k take particular note, in this diagram, that a cutaneous palmar branch of the median nerve, which serves the skin at the base of the hand and the central palm, passes superficial to the flexor retinaculum . because this nerve does not pass through the carpal tunnel, skin in the central palm is unaffected in carpal tunnel syndrome. skin supplied by the main branch, which passes through the carpal tunnel, is affected . at the wrist, identify the median nerve medial to the flexor carpi radialis tendon. follow it into the carpal tunnel with the long flexor tendons (flexor digitorum superficialis, flexor digitorum profundus and flexor pollicis longus) . compression of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel leads to carpal tunnel syndrome.

16.1 innervation by the ulnar nerve 11 previous next epicondyle. at about the midway point of the forearm, reflect the flexor carpi ulnaris medially and find the ulnar nerve there, like the filling in a sandwich , between the flexor carpi ulnaris and the medial (“ulnar”) half of flexor digitorum profundus . the “ulnar” half of flexor digitorum profundus flexes the dip joints of digits 4 and 5 . follow the ulnar nerve to the wrist, where it passes, superficial to the carpal tunnel, into the hand. as you will learn, the ulnar nerve innervates most of the intrinsic muscles of the hand. identify the ulnar nerve passing posterior to the medial tas k

16.1 where was that radial pulse? 12 previous next and find its point of bifurcation into the radial and ulnar arteries. trace the radial artery along the lateral aspect of the forearm to the wrist, at the cubital fossa, identify the brachial artery tas k where it passes lateral to the tendon of the flexor carpi radialis. identify the tendon of the flexor carpi radialis in your own wrist and find your radial pulse lateral to it. trace the ulnar artery to where it disappears deep to the pronator teres. find it again in the medial aspect of the wrist in the company of the ulnar nerve. notice that it, like the ulnar nerve, passes superficial to the carpal tunnel.

16.1 progress check 1 13 previous next since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: identify the three borders of the cubital fossa. identify the radial, median and ulnar nerves in the region of the cubital fossa. identify the contents of the cubital fossa present in your prosection and describe those that have been removed in its creation. identify, and describe the action and innervation of, the muscles of the anterior compartment of the forearm. identify the nerves and blood vessels of the anterior compartments of the forearm. identify the carpal tunnel and its contents. identify, in dissection and in surface anatomy, the tendons, nerves and blood vessels associated with the anterior aspect of the wrist. describe the motor distribution of the median nerve. describe the motor distribution of the ulnar nerve in the forearm trace the blood supply to the forearm, starting with the brachial artery in the arm. identify all pulse points. if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on.

16.1 posterior compartment overview 14 previous next some general comments: the muscles of the posterior compartment of the forearm are organized into two layers. the muscles of the first layer arise from the lateral epicondyle of the humerus, the common extensor origin (ceo), and the adjacent supracondyler ridge. of the four deeper muscles, three act on the thumb. all muscles in this compartment are innervated by the radial nerve. the superficial layer consists of six muscles (red). one flexes the elbow. the others extend the wrist and fingers. two muscles of the deep layer are seen at the level of this cross section. the posterior compartment of the forearm can be referred to as the “extensor-supinator” compartment. muscles of this compartment supinate the forearm and extend the radiocarpal, metacarpophalangeal, and proximal and distal interphalangeal joints. the words “extensor” and “supinator” are common in the names of its muscles.

16.1 the superficial layer: brachioradialis 15 previous next the mass of muscles arising from the ceo. identify the brachioradialis as the most lateral muscle, and the muscle with the turn the prosected arm over and identify tas k most proximal point of origin. its name tells you its attachments, and that it crosses only the elbow joint. notice that the brachioradialis muscle crosses anterior to the elbow joint (blue arrow) to insert into the distal radius. what is its action, if it crosses anterior to the elbow joint? think, then click: its action makes the brachioradialis an exception in the “extensor-supinator” compartment.

16.1 the superficial layer: extensors of the wrist and fingers 16 previous next of the forearm adjacent to the brachioradialis. notice that their tendons cross the posterior (extensor) aspect of the wrist (carpi) on its lateral side (radialis). these muscles are the extensor carpi radialis longus and the extensor carpi radialis brevis. observe that the next muscle has four tendons that cross the posterior (extensor) aspect of the fingers (digitorum). the tendons of the extensor digitorum insert into the extensor expansions, ct structures that anchor the tendons to the bases of the distal two phalanges. extensor digitorum, therefore, is an extensor of the mcp, pip and dip joints. you might notice a small accessory extensor muscle that is dedicated to the fifth finger, the extensor digiti minimi. identify the final and most medial muscle in this layer, the extensor carpi ulnaris (ecu). follow its tendon across the posterior aspect of the wrist on its medial side. identify the two muscles in the posterior compartment tas k

16.1 extensor expansions 17 previous next the position of a finger is determined by the balance of pull of its flexors and extensors. the tendons of the digital extensors are seen on the dorsal aspect of the hand , the extensor digitorum, and extensor pollicis longus muscles . these digital extensor muscles insert into the dorsal aspect of the digits via elaborate ct structures called extensor expansions or hoods. via these structures, the digital extensor muscles pull across the dorsal aspect of the mcp, pip and dip joints simultaneously, thereby extending all joints, indiscriminately. yet, you are able to flex your mcp, pip and dip joints independently! how? this is, in part, because the tendons of the long flexor muscles , arising in the anterior compartment of the forearm, allow us to flex these joints individually. in addition, intrinsic muscles of the hand, the lumbricals and dorsal interossei facilitate independent movement of the mcp, pip and dip, as is explained with the study of the hand.

16.1 which muscles abduct and adduct the wrist? 18 previous next the radial aspect of the wrist. they are the flexor carpi radialis, the extensor carpi radialis longus and the extensor carpi radialis brevis. these muscles, all with carpi radialis in their names, contract synergistically to pull across the lateral aspect of the wrist, causing abduction. identify the three tendons crossing tas k crossing the ulnar aspect of the wrist. they are the flexor carpi ulnaris and the extensor carpi ulnaris. these muscles, both with carpi ulnaris in their names, contract synergistically to pull across the medial aspect of the wrist, causing adduction. identify the two tendons tas k this figure illustrates that: tendons of adductors pull across the medial (ulnar) aspect of the wrist (green arrow) tendons of abductors pull across the lateral (radial) aspect of the wrist (purple arrow).

16.1 the deep layer 19 previous next a deep muscle of the proximal forearm assists the biceps brachii in supinating the forearm. the blue arrow illustrates that, like the biceps brachii, it laterally rotates the radius. carpi radialis brevis and the extensor digitorum, the deep extensor muscles of the forearm . follow the three tendons to the thumb; each attaches to a identify, emerging from between the extensor tas k extensor pollicis brevis are involved in the common problem of dequervain’s tenosynovitis. follow the tendon of the extensor pollicis longus around the the tendons of the abductor pollicis longus and info different bone, and therefore each muscle acts on a different joint. traveling together are the tendons of the abductor pollicis longus (apl) and extensor pollicis brevis (epb). follow the former to the first metacarpal; it abducts the carpometacarpal joint of the thumb. follow the latter to the first phalange; it extends both the carpometacarpal and mcp joints of the thumb. dorsal tubercle of the radius to the second phalange. it extends all three joints of the thumb. lastly, you may notice the tendon of an accessory extensor of the index finger, the extensor indices.

16.1 the anatomical snuffbox 20 previous next extensor pollicis longus forming the posterior border of your anatomical snuffbox. now identify the tendons of the extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus forming the anterior border of your anatomical snuffbox. do you see your cephalic vein passing through your anatomical snuffbox? recall from unit 2 that it is used for venous cannulation in this region. in the floor of the anatomical snuffbox is the scaphoid bone, the most commonly fractured carpal bone. the anatomical snuffbox is used for examination of the scaphoid bone in a suspected fracture. extend your wrist and identify the tendon of tas k

16.1 nerve and blood supply 21 previous muscles. follow its superficial branch distally in the shelter of the brachioradialis muscle to the wrist. it is cutaneous to the dorsolateral aspect of the hand (green). identify the radial nerve lateral to the cubital fossa, between the brachialis and brachioradialis tas k turn the prosection over. identify the continuation of the radial nerve in the posterior compartment of the forearm. it innervates all muscles of this compartment, and therefore is responsible for extension of the wrist, thumb and fingers. the midshaft of the humerus, the wrist rests in a flexed position due to paralysis of its extensor muscles. this is called “drop wrist”. if the lesion is with a lesion of the radial nerve at, or distal to, info you are finished with this prosection. moisten it and drape it with a damp cloth . higher, i.e. at or above the axilla, elbow extension will be weak as well . next

16.1 progress check 2 22 previous next since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: identify, and describe the action and innervation of, the muscles of the posterior compartment of the forearm. describe the structure and function of the extensor expansions. identify the muscles responsible for abduction and adduction of the wrist. identify the tendons that border the anatomical snuffbox. what bone forms its floor? what artery and vein pass through it? describe the motor distribution of the radial nerve. describe the cause and appearance of “drop wrist”. describe the cutaneous distribution of the superficial branch of the radial nerve. if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on.

16.2 the leg, ankle and foot back to station selection next specimens lower limb bone box articulated bony foot articulated lower limb lower limb joint box prosected lower limb

16.2 objectives 2 previous next when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to identify and describe: the major muscles acting on the ankle and foot, and their actions, the nerves of the leg and foot, including both their motor and sensory distributions

16.2 borders of the popliteal fossa 3 previous next the popliteal fossa provides the major route by which structures pass between the thigh and the leg. it is a diamond-shaped regions posterior to the knee, analogous to the cubital fossa in the upper limb. and place it prone on the table. identify the muscular borders of the popliteal fossa. identify the hamstring muscles forming its borders superomedially and superolaterally. identify, forming its inferomedial and inferolateral borders, the medial and lateral heads of the gastrocnemius muscle, respectively. identify, forming its floor, the fibrous capsule of the knee joint, the popliteal surface of the femur and the posterior aspect of the proximal tibia. unwrap the prosected lower limb tas k

16.2 content of the popliteal fossa 4 previous next popliteal artery and popliteal vein. recall that other structures and much adipose tissue will have been removed in the creation of this specimen, including lymphatic vessels and lymph nodes, and a large amount of adipose tissue. in life, the popliteal fossa is enclosed superficially by the deep fascia of the leg, which is continuous superiorly with the fascia lata and inferiorly with the crural fascia. the superficial fascia in this region contains the small saphenous vein and cutaneous nerves. the small saphenous vein pierces the deep fascia overlying the popliteal fossa and empties into the popliteal vein. identify the contents of the tas k popliteal fossa that are present in the prosection: the tibial and common fibular nerves, the

16.2 nerves of the popliteal fossa 5 previous next nerves proximally, and realize that they are the continuation of the sciatic nerve from the posterior compartment of the follow the tibial and common fibular tas k compression of the nerve here causes sensory and motor symptoms in its area of distribution . cutaneous sensation over the lateral aspect of the proximal leg is spared, however, as the lateral cutaneous nerve of the calf arises proximal to the point of compression at the fibular neck . the relationship of the common fibular nerve to the neck of the fibula is clinically important. info thigh. the tibial division of the sciatic nerve is primarily responsible for the innervation of the hamstring muscles. follow the tibial nerve distally, through the midline of the popliteal fossa, and into the posterior compartment of the leg. follow the common fibular nerve around the lateral aspect of the knee in close association with the tendon of the biceps femoris. here the common fibular nerve gives an important cutaneous branch, the lateral cutaneous nerve of the calf. follow the common fibular branch around the neck of the fibula into the lateral compartment of the leg.

16.2 blood vessels of the popliteal fossa 6 previous next in the popliteal fossa. follow them proximally, through the adductor hiatus into the anterior compartment of the identify the popliteal artery and vein tas k thigh, and realize that they are continuous with the femoral artery and vein. in the popliteal fossa, the popliteal vessels give a number of geniculate branches that anastomose around, and supply, the knee. follow the popliteal artery distally into the proximal leg and find its point of bifurcation into the anterior and posterior tibial arteries. follow the anterior tibial artery until it disappears through an opening in the crural interosseous membrane into the anterior compartment of the leg. that is present in the popliteal fossa and because of the depth of the popliteal artery, a popliteal pulse can be difficult to palpate. because of the large amount of fat info

16.2 the posterior superficial compartment of the leg 7 previous next the tendon of insertion of the muscles in the posterior superficial compartment. follow it to the tuberosity of the calcaneus. because these muscles, when they contract, pull up on the calcaneus, they push the toes down, thus plantarflex the talocrural joint. identify the calcaneal (achilles) tendon, tas k the gastrocnemius muscle. notice that they originate proximal to the knee joint, and so are capable of contributing to flexion of the knee as well as plantarflexion of the talocrural joint. observe that the two heads of the gastrocnemius fuse to form a single muscle belly, which is identifiable in surface anatomy as the “calf” of the leg. identify the medial and lateral heads of tas k identify the soleus muscle, deep to the gastrocnemius. notice that it originates in the leg, and so acts only on the talocrural joint, where it contributes to plantarflexion.

16.2 vessels of the posterior leg 8 previous next on the medial aspect of the prosected leg, the origin of the soleus from the tibia has been cut. this allows you to reflect it gently to study deeper structures. beneath it to find the neurovascular structures located in the plane between the superficial and deep posterior compartments of the leg. on the medial aspect of the leg, reflect the soleus laterally and look tas k although the deep fascia that separates the superficial and deep compartments of the leg has been removed in this prosection, realize that these neurovascular structures are, in fact, located deep to this facial plane in the posterior deep compartment. proximally, once again identify the popliteal artery and its bifurcation into the anterior and posterior tibial arteries. note, from this aspect, the anterior tibial artery passes through the interosseous membrane into the anterior compartment of the leg. follow the posterior tibial artery and identify its fibular branch. the fibular artery sends penetrating branches through the posterior intermuscular septum into the lateral compartment of the leg. follow the posterior tibial artery as it passes posterior to the medial malleolus into the foot. whether they are present in the prosection or not, realize that deep veins run parallel to the arteries and take the same name.

16.2 nerves of the posterior leg 9 previous next artery throughout its course in the posterior leg. note branches of the tibial nerve supplying the muscles of the posterior superficial and deep compartments. identify the tibial nerve accompanying the posterior tibial tas k follow these structures pass posterior to the medial malleolus, through the tarsal tunnel, enter the foot. look for the sural nerve, a branch of the tibial nerve, located superficial to the lateral head of the gastrocnemius muscle. the sural nerve pierces the deep fascia of the leg to enter the superficial fascia and provides cutaneous sensation to the lateral aspect of the distal leg and foot.

16.2 the posterior deep compartment of the leg 10 previous next compartment of the leg. notice that the tendons of all three of these muscles pass behind the medial malleolus and into the sole of the foot. identify the bellies of the three muscles of the posterior deep tas k on the medial side of the leg, identify the muscle belly of the flexor digitorum longus. in the diagram, note that in the foot it forms four tendons that cross the plantar aspect of the lateral four toes. contraction of the flexor digitorum longus curls the toes under, i.e. it is a flexor of the lateral four toes, as its name suggests. it is important in the push-off phase of the gait cycle. on the lateral side of the leg, identify the muscle belly of the flexor hallucis longus. in the diagram, follow the tendons of the flexor hallucis longus across the plantar aspect of the great toe. contraction of the flexor hallucis longus curls the great toe under, i.e. it is a flexor of the great toe, as its name suggests. this muscle is important in propelling us forward during the gait cycle and upward when we jump. notice that the positions of these muscle bellies are on opposite sides of the limb with respect to their points of insertion . this necessitates that their tendons cross in the sole of the foot as illustrated in the diagram. identify the intermediate muscle, the tibialis posterior, tp. in the diagram, follow the tendon of the tp to the medial aspect of the foot. when the muscle contracts, it pulls up on the medial aspect of the foot to cause inversion. it is also important in supporting the medial longitudinal arch of the foot.

turn your attention 16.2 the tarsal tunnel 11 previous next to the region posteroinferior to the medial malleolus. note the presence of tas k · tendon of tibialis posterior · tendon of flexor digitorum longus · posterior tibial artery (& veins) · tibial nerve · tendon of flexor hallucis longus a mnemonic often used to remember this order is: tom, dick and not harry. palpate the pulse of the posterior tibial artery through the flexor retinaculum, midway between the medial malleolus and the calcaneus. the long flexor tendons and neurovascular structures in this region. confirm the order of structures, starting at the medial malleolus. it is:

16.2 the plantar aponeurosis previous next dense thickening of deep fascia called the plantar aponeurosis. it consists of a thick condensation of dense regular ct that extends along the length of the sole of the foot. note its proximal attachment to the calcaneal tuberosity and the digital bands it forms distally, which extend into the toes to attach firmly to bone, ligament and dermis. the plantar aponeurosis supports the longitudinal arches of the foot and protects the deeper structures of the foot. identify, on the plantar aspect of the foot, a tas k plantar fasciitis info click here for more info 12

16.2 summary of supports for the arches of the foot 13 previous next the numerous dense ct structures that support the arches in the sole of the foot are summarized here. dense plantar ligaments bind the tarsal bones together. the tendons of tibialis posterior and tibialis anterior, both invertors of the foot, attach to its medial aspect and support the medial longitudinal arch. the tendon of the fibularis longus, which everts the foot, crosses the sole of the foot from lateral to medial to support the lateral longitudinal arch. lastly, the plantar aponeurosis binds the tuberosity of the calcaneus to the ball of the foot, defining the distance between the two, and thereby supporting the arches.

16.2 intrinsic muscles of the foot 14 previous next so far, you’ve learned about extrinsic muscles of the foot, i.e. muscles that originate in the leg and insert in the foot. the sole of the foot, like the palm of the hand, contains numerous intrinsic muscles. these muscles are wholly within the foot. some act on the mtp joints to cause abduction / adduction and flexion / extension, while others act on the pips and dips to cause flexion . you are not responsible for learning the details regarding the intrinsic muscles of the sole of the foot. the tibial nerve, on entering the sole of the foot bifurcates to form the medial and lateral plantar nerves, which innervate all intrinsic muscles of the sole of the foot. the posterior tibial artery gives similarly-named branches, the medial and lateral plantar arteries. the tibial nerve gives a calcaneal branch that supplies the skin overlying the heel of the foot. cutaneous sensation to most of the sole of the foot is provided by the medial plantar nerve, with the remainder provided by the lateral plantar nerve. the saphenous and sural nerves supply the medial and lateral surfaces of the foot, respectively.

16.2 progress check 1 15 previous next since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: identify the muscular borders of the popliteal fossa, and the structures that form its floor. identify the contents of the popliteal fossa present in your prosection and describe those that have been removed in its creation. identify, and describe the action and innervation of, the muscles of the posterior superficial and deep compartments of the leg. identify the nerves and blood vessels of the posterior compartments of the leg. describe the motor distribution of the tibial nerve. describe the cutaneous distribution of its branches, the sural nerve, calcaneal nerve, medial and lateral plantar nerve. describe the cutaneous distribution of the saphenous nerve. what is its parent nerve? identify and describe the contents of the tarsal tunnel. name the branches of the tibial nerve and posterior tibial artery in the foot. identify the plantar aponeurosis and describe the structures that support the arches of the foot. describe the cutaneous distribution of the calcaneal, and medial and lateral plantar nerves. if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on.

16.2 muscles of the lateral compartment of the leg 16 previous next leg is facing up. identify the two muscles of the lateral compartment, the fibularis longus and fibularis brevis. turn the prosection such that the lateral side of the tas k know that these muscles were previously know as the peroneus longus and brevis. despite the fact that they were renamed 50 years ago, clinicians may still refer to them using these obsolete names. notice that the fibularis longus arises from the proximal fibula, and the fibularis brevis arises deep to the longus, from the distal fibula. follow the tendons of these muscle around the lateral malleolus. note the attachment of the fibularis brevis to the base of the fifth metatarsal, and observe that the fibularis longus disappears from view into the sole of the foot. as illustrated, the fibularis longus tendon crosses the sole of the foot to attach at its medial side. these muscles pull upward on the lateral aspect of the foot. what is their action? don’t click here until you think of your answer .

16.2 innervation of the lateral compartment of the leg 17 previous next biceps femoris. note the attachment of the biceps femoris to the fibular head, and that the common fibular nerve swings laterally around the neck of the fibula into the lateral compartment of the leg. locate the common fibular nerve adjacent to the tendon of the tas k as illustrated, the common fibular nerve bifurcates, forming the superficial and deep fibular nerves . the superficial fibular nerve innervates the fibularis longus and fibularis brevis. look for the superficial fibular nerve emerging from the lateral compartment of the leg and continuing onto the dorsum of the foot, where it provides cutaneous sensation. recall that the sural nerve provides cutaneous sensation to the lateral aspect of the leg and foot. also, recall that there are no major vessels in the lateral compartment of the leg, but that it receives blood from perforating branches of the fibular artery.

16.2 muscles of the anterior compartment of the leg 18 previous next talocrural joint. these arise from the muscles of the anterior compartment of the leg. what common action do these muscles share? include both the action and the joint in your answer. think then click: identify the tendons crossing the anterior aspect of the tas k identify the muscle belly located most medially. this is the tibialis anterior muscle. follow the tendon of the tibialis anterior across the anterior aspect of the talocrural joint to its point of attachment on the medial aspect of the foot. what action, in addition to dorsiflexion of the talocrural joint, does the tibialis anterior contribute to? think of your answer before clicking here: . what muscle, located in the posterior deep compartment, also attaches to the medial aspect of the foot and has the same action as ta? think first! now identify the muscle belly located most laterally. it is the extensor digitorum longus. follow its tendon into the foot and note that it forms four tendons, which cross the superior aspect of the lateral four toes. what is the action of this muscle? think first, click second! identify, intermediate between the tibialis anterior and extensor digitorum longus, the muscle belly of the extensor hallucis longus. follow its tendon into the foot and across the superior aspect of the great toe. what is the action of the extensor hallucis longus? think then click!

16.2 innervation of the anterior compartment of the leg 19 previous next adjacent to the crural interosseous membrane, locate the deep fibular nerve and the anterior tibial artery. between the tibialis anterior and the extensor hallucis longus, tas k do you remember what nerve the deep fibular nerve branches from? do you remember what artery the anterior tibial artery arises from? recall that after the common fibular nerve passes around the neck of the fibula and enters the lateral compartment of the leg, it bifurcates into the superficial fibular nerve and the deep fibular nerve. the superficial nerve supplies muscles of the lateral compartment of the leg. the deep fibular nerve supplies muscles of the anterior compartment of the leg. recall that when the popliteal artery enters the posterior deep compartment of the leg, it bifurcates into the anterior and posterior tibial arteries, and that the anterior tibial artery passes through an opening in the crural interosseous membrane to enter the anterior compartment of the leg.

16.2 synovial tendon sheaths 20 previous next as depicted, extensor retinacula bind down the long extensor tendons in the region of the ankle. these retinacula are thickenings of the deep fascia of the leg (i.e. crural fascia) and foot. if they are present in your prosection. if they are not, be sure to identify them on the appropriate specimen in grant’s museum. identify the extensor retinacula, tas k synovial tendon sheaths will have been removed during the creation of the prosection, as these are composed of delicate synovial membrane. know that in life, synovial tendon sheaths surround the long extensor tendons and facilitate their movement in a friction-free manner relative to their bony and fibrous surroundings. this is analogous to the synovial tendon sheaths of the long flexor tendons of the hand.

16.2 the dorsum of the foot 21 previous next the tendons of the extensor digitorum longus, the muscle bellies of the extensor digitorum brevis. note that its tendons join those of the extensor digitorum longus and extensor hallucis longus to assist with extension of the toes. focus your attention on the dorsum of the foot. identify, deep to tas k anterior tibial artery in the dorsum of the foot. remember that you can take a pulse here, just lateral to the tendon of the ehl. look for the continuation of the deep fibular nerve in the dorsum of the foot. look for the dorsalis pedis artery, the continuation of the tas k it innervates the extensor digitorum brevis, and provides cutaneous sensation to the first webspace, as illustrated in bright yellow in the accompanying diagram. recall that cutaneous innervation of most of the dorsum of the foot is supplied by the superficial fibular nerve, of the lateral aspect of the leg and foot is the sural nerve, and that the medial aspect of the leg and foot is supplied by the saphenous nerve, which is the only branch of the femoral nerve that extends below the knee. clinically, the extensor digitorum brevis forms a perceptible mound on the lateral aspect of the dorsum of the foot. it can be mistaken for a localized swelling, if you are not aware of its presence.

16.2 summary of motor nerves of the leg and foot 22 previous next with the nerve that controls them. associate, in your mind, the actions of the muscles within a fascial compartment tas k muscles of the posterior superficial compartment of the leg plantarflex the talocrural joint and contribute to flexion of the knee. muscles of the posterior deep compartment of the leg invert the foot and flex the toes. muscles of the sole of the foot abduct / adduct the toes and contribute to flexion of the toes. all these muscles are controlled by the tibial nerve and its branches. muscles of the lateral compartment of the leg evert the foot; they are innervated by the superficial fibular (peroneal) nerve. muscles of the anterior compartment of the leg dorsiflex the talocrural joint, invert the foot and extend the toes. intrinsic muscles of the dorsum of the foot contribute to extension of the toes. all these muscles are innervated by the deep fibular (peroneal) nerve.

16.2 summary of cutaneous nerves of the leg and foot i 23 previous next as you traced the major peripheral nerves through the lower limb, you learned the following about their cutaneous distribution. in your mind’s eye, recall tracing the nerves as follows: recall that when you followed the femoral nerve through the anterior compartment of the thigh, you found that it had only one branch that extended beyond the knee, the saphenous nerve, and that this nerve is cutaneous to the medial aspect of the leg and foot. recall that the lateral cutaneous nerve of the calf supplies the lateral aspect of the proximal leg, and that this branch arises from the common peroneal nerve proximal to the fibular head. compression of the common peroneal nerve at the fibular head therefore spares this area of skin. recall that the superficial peroneal nerve becomes cutaneous after supplying the muscles of the lateral compartment of the leg, and is distributed to the lateral aspect of the distal leg and the dorsum of the foot. the exception is the skin of the first webspace, which is supplied by the deep peroneal nerve .

16.2 summary of cutaneous nerves of the leg and foot ii 24 previous next recall that in the popliteal fossa, you looked for the sural nerve, a branch of the tibial nerve, that descends with the short saphenous vein in the superficial fascia of the calf to supply cutaneous sensation to the lateral aspect of the distal leg and foot. recall that when you followed the tibial nerve into the foot, you learned of a calcaneal branch supplying cutaneous sensation to the heel. you then learned that the tibial nerve bifurcates, forming the medial and lateral plantar nerves, which supply cutaneous sensation to the medial and lateral aspects of the sole of the foot .

16.2 progress check 2 25 previous next since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: identify, and describe the action and innervation of, the muscles of the lateral compartment of the leg. identify their tendons posterior to the lateral malleolus. describe the blood supply to the lateral compartment of the leg. identify, and describe the action and innervation of, the muscles of the anterior compartment of the leg. identify their tendons anterior to the talocrural joint and on the dorsum of the foot. describe the blood supply to the anterior compartment of the leg. describe the cutaneous distribution of the branches of the common fibular nerve: the lateral cutaneous nerve of the calf, and the superficial and deep peroneal (fibular) nerves. describe the structure and function of the synovial tendon sheaths of the foot. identify and describe the structures of the dorsum of the foot. trace the blood supply to the leg, starting with the popliteal artery and identify all pulse points. if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on.
